Comment:
Hi everyone!

I think this is my second worst game I have played against Master Freddy.  I played like my OTB rating here.  My OTB rating is still 1200.  If you see what happened from the middlegame onwards you will see why.  Freddy opens with the Gedault Opening, 1. f3.
1. ...... e5 - the most common response to this pawn move.
2.  Nc3 - aha, Freddy does not follow up with the Fried Fox, Pork Chop Opening, which is 2. Kf2.  This knight move of Freddy's to c3 transposes into his favourite opening which is the Dunst!

4. ....... Nc6 - and this becomes like the Centre Game but with the e pawn on e2 and not e4.  I decide to develop a piece.  Freddy chooses to tuck his queen, that Wicked Witch of the West onto f2.  You will see why as the game develops.

4. ....... Nc6 - and this becomes like the Centre Game but with the e pawn on e2 and not e4.  I decide to develop a piece.  Freddy chooses to tuck his queen, that Wicked Witch of the West onto f2.  You will see why as the game develops.

4. ....... Nc6 - and this becomes like the Centre Game but with the e pawn on e2 and not e4.  I decide to develop a piece.  Freddy chooses to tuck his queen, that Wicked Witch of the West onto f2.  You will see why as the game develops.

4. ....... Nc6 - and this becomes like the Centre Game but with the e pawn on e2 and not e4.  I decide to develop a piece.  Freddy chooses to tuck his queen, that Wicked Witch of the West onto f2.  You will see why as the game develops.

4. ....... Nc6 - and this becomes like the Centre Game but with the e pawn on e2 and not e4.  I decide to develop a piece.  Freddy chooses to tuck his queen, that Wicked Witch of the West onto f2.  You will see why as the game develops.

5. ..... Bb4 - pins the knight on c3 and develops a piece.  I am now wondering whether the move Be7, although more passive would have been more circumspect here.  For starters it defends the knight on f6.

5. ..... Bb4 - pins the knight on c3 and develops a piece.  I am now wondering whether the move Be7, although more passive would have been more circumspect here.  For starters it defends the knight on f6.

7. ........ Qe7.  I start to clear the decks so that I can choose whether to castle kingside or queenside.  I would prefer to castle queenside, same side as Freddy this time, but there is the possibility of Freddy putting a knight on d5.  Freddy prepares for it by playing e4.  This move makes Nd5 a very strong move because if there is an exchange of knights on d5, the e pawn will recapture, threaten the c6 knight and open up the possibility of a rook pin on the e column.  Henry and Glenda are really sitting ducks there!

8. ........ Bxc3 - so I avoid this possibility by making a concession.  Fou Lenoir gives up his life for that knight but now Freddy's dsb goes to c3.  That dsb's control of the a1-h8 diagonal will open up the possibility of a combo against the f6 knight later on.

8. ........ Bxc3 - so I avoid this possibility by making a concession.  Fou Lenoir gives up his life for that knight but now Freddy's dsb goes to c3.  That dsb's control of the a1-h8 diagonal will open up the possibility of a combo against the f6 knight later on.
9. ...... b6 - prepares a fianchetto of Fou Leblanc on b7.
9. ...... b6 - prepares a fianchetto of Fou Leblanc on b7.
11. .......... 0-0-0? - I feel that I have enough breathing space to make this move.  I think in hindsight I should have prepared this by moving my rook to g8 first.
11. .......... 0-0-0? - I feel that I have enough breathing space to make this move.  I think in hindsight I should have prepared this by moving my rook to g8 first.
11. .......... 0-0-0? - I feel that I have enough breathing space to make this move.  I think in hindsight I should have prepared this by moving my rook to g8 first.

12. Ng3 - I thought he was going to move his knight to f5 or h5 threatening to invade, which prompted the blunder, g6??

12. ..... g6?? - the rot sets in as early as the 12th move.  Incredibly this is the only time such a thing has happened in my game against Freddy, me being lost in just a dozen moves!!!  Now here comes the combo.  Admittedly it takes four moves before the devastation becomes apparent, but at my level I should have seen it coming.
13. ........ Bxc6 - this knight trade accomplishes two things.  1.  The Witch can now come to d4.  2.  Fou Leblanc is lured onto a square where he is hanging.
13. ........ Bxc6 - this knight trade accomplishes two things.  1.  The Witch can now come to d4.  2.  Fou Leblanc is lured onto a square where he is hanging.
14. ...... Nd7 - naturally I move my knight out of the way as Qxh8 results in the loss of 2 rooks for the Witch for me.  But Fou Leblanc is hanging and now Freddy exploits this.
14. ...... Nd7 - naturally I move my knight out of the way as Qxh8 results in the loss of 2 rooks for the Witch for me.  But Fou Leblanc is hanging and now Freddy exploits this.
15. ...... Bb7 - I now have the grim choice.  Lose Fou Leblanc or the exchange.  I choose to save Fou Leblanc.
15. ...... Bb7 - I now have the grim choice.  Lose Fou Leblanc or the exchange.  I choose to save Fou Leblanc.
17. ...... f6 - after the horse has bolted, the stable door shuts.
17. ...... f6 - after the horse has bolted, the stable door shuts.
17. ...... f6 - after the horse has bolted, the stable door shuts.
17. ...... f6 - after the horse has bolted, the stable door shuts.

19. ....... Qd7 - In retrospect Rd8 should have been played here.  Guess I was in a state of shock over what happened a few moves back.  It is so easy to be in this state after something so awful.  When this happens it is quite possible that more mistakes can be made.  So is the case here.

20. ........ c5?? - if I had played my rook to d8 this move would have been OK, but it drops a further pawn.

22.......... Ng4 - trying to make the best of a rotten job.
